title: 112_hr2681
content: The "Cement Sector Regulatory Relief Act of 2011" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Legislative stay is addressed in Section 2. The "Cement Sector Regulatory Relief Act of 2011" authorizes the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to propose regulations for the Portland cement manufacturing industry and plants, establishing control technology standards and identifying non-hazardous materials for use as fuels. The "Cement Sector Regulatory Relief Act of 2011" authorizes the EPA to propose regulations for the cement manufacturing industry, including solid waste combustion units, under the Solid Waste Disposal Act. The regulations must be finalized within 15 months of the Act's enactment, replacing earlier rules. The "Cement Sector Regulatory Relief Act of 2011" authorizes the EPA to propose regulations for the cement manufacturing industry, including solid waste combustion units. Rules from 75 Fed. Reg. 54970 and 76 Fed. Reg. 15704 will be replaced as described in subsection (a). The EPA is proposing regulations for the cement manufacturing industry, including solid waste combustion units. The EPA is proposing regulations for the cement manufacturing industry, including solid waste combustion units. Compliance dates are specified in Section 3. The EPA is proposing regulations for the cement manufacturing industry, including solid waste combustion units. Compliance dates for these regulations will be set by the Administrator, not earlier than 5 years after the effective date of the regulation, taking into account costs, health and environmental impacts, energy requirements, and feasibility of implementation. The Administrator will propose regulations for the cement manufacturing industry, including solid waste combustion units. The date of proposal will determine the classification of new sources under the Clean Air Act, considering equipment availability, labor, and potential employment impacts. The Clean Air Act does not restrict the provisions of certain sections related to cement manufacturing industry regulations. SEC. 4. ENERGY RECOVERY AND CONSERVATION. In promulgating rules under section 2(a) related to energy recovery and conservation, the Administrator must adopt specific definitions and identify non-hazardous secondary material as solid waste. The Administrator must adopt specific definitions for non-hazardous secondary material as solid waste, including criteria for commercial and industrial waste or contained gaseous material. SEC. 5. OTHER PROVISIONS. In promulgating rules under section 2(a), the Administrator must ensure emissions standards for existing and new sources can be met under actual operating conditions. Regulatory alternatives authorized under the Clean Air Act must be considered, with the imposition of the least burdensome option. The Administrator must impose the least burdensome regulatory option under the Clean Air Act and Executive Order No. 13563. The House of Representatives passed the document on October 6, 2011, with Karen L. Haas as the Clerk.
